coredata.dc:description: In 2015, the United Nations created 17 Sustainable Development Goals. Sustainable Development Goal 3, “Good Health and Wellbeing,” includes 13 health target metric goals. This short report describes how advanced practice nurses (APNs) have addressed Goal 3 around the world. Given the variation in the APN roles internationally, it is important to capture common aspects of projects conducted during the first 5 years of this initiative. This report serves as a template for further evaluations of the importance of APNs in supporting global health policies. These findings inform how the workforce can effectively pursue these goals.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: APN Activities Illustrating Support of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 3 (UN SDG3) Target Indicators

row.entry: UN SDG3 Target
Target Indicators
Example by Country, APN Role, Publication
3.1. By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.

3.1.1 Maternal mortality ratio
3.1.2 Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel

Country: United States
APN role: CNM
Carlson et al 18

3.2. By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2.1 Under-5 mortality rate
3.2.2 Neonatal mortality rate

Country: United Kingdom
APN role: NP
Kossarova et al 23
Country: New Zealand
APN role: CNS
Weston 35

3.3 By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome), tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases.

3.3.1 Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population, by sex, age, and key populations
3.3.2 Tuberculosis incidence per 100,000 population
3.3.3 Malaria incidence per 1,000 population
3.3.4 Hepatitis B incidence per 100,000 population
3.3.5 Number of people requiring interventions against neglected tropical diseases

Country: United Kingdom
APN role: CNS
Royal College of Nursing 31
Country: South Africa
APN role: NP
Farley et al 20
Country: Zambia
APN role: NP
McCullock et al 27
Country: Australia
APN role: clinical nurse consultant
STI & BBV Section 34
3.4 By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.

3.4.1 Mortality rate attributed to cardiovascular disease, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory disease
3.4.2 Suicide mortality rate

Country: Philippines
APN role: APN
Jittawadee et al 21
Country: Netherlands
APN role: NP
Kok et al 22
Country: Thailand
APN role: NP
Phuangngoenmak et al 30
Country: Ireland
APN role: CNS
Davis & McDonnell 19
Country: United States
APN role: NP
Bounds et al 38
3.5 Strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, including narcotic drug abuse and harmful use of alcohol.

3.5.1 Coverage of treatment interventions (pharmacological, psychosocial and rehabilitation and aftercare services) for substance use disorders
3.5.2 Harmful use of alcohol, defined according to the national context as alcohol per capita consumption (aged 15 years and older) within a calendar year in litres of pure alcohol

Country: New Zealand
APN role: NP
Manchester 26
3.6 By 2020, halve the number of global deaths and injuries from road traffic accidents.
3.6.1 Death rate due to road traffic injuries

Country: Brazil
APN role: NP
Patel et al 29

3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7.1 Proportion of women of reproductive age (aged 15–49 years) who have their need for family planning satisfied with modern methods
3.7.2 Adolescent birth rate (aged 10–14 years; aged 15–19 years) per 1,000 women in that age group

Country: Canada
APN role: NP
Smith 33

3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality, and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8.1 Coverage of essential health services (defined as the average coverage of essential services based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases and service capacity and access, among the general and the most disadvantaged population)
3.8.2 Proportion of population with large household expenditures on health as a share of total household expenditure or income

Country: Global
APN role: All roles
Bryant-Lukosius et al 17
Lopatina et al 25
3.9 By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

3.9.1 Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution.
3.9.2 Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water, unsafe sanitation, and lack of hygiene (exposure to unsafe Water, Sanitation and Hygiene for All (WASH) services)
3.9.3 Mortality rate attributed to unintentional poisoning

Country: United States
APN role: NP
National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners 28
Country: Tanzania
APN role: NP
Lekei et al 24
3.a Strengthen the implementation of the World Health Organization Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in all countries, as appropriate.
3.a.1 Age-standardized prevalence of current tobacco use among persons aged 15 years and older

Country: United States
APN Title: NP
National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners 28

3.b Support the research and development of vaccines and medicines for the communicable and non-communicable diseases that primarily affect developing countries, provide access to affordable essential medicines and vaccines, in accordance with the Doha Declaration on the TRIPS Agreement and Public Health, which affirms the right of developing countries to use to the full the provisions in the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights regarding flexibilities to protect public health, and, in particular, provide access to medicines for all.

3.b.1 Proportion of the target population covered by all vaccines included in their national programme
3.b.2 Total net official development assistance to medical research and basic health sectors
3.b.3 Proportion of health facilities that have a core set of relevant essential medicines available and affordable on a sustainable basis

Country: United States
APN role: NP
Williams 36

3.c Substantially increase health financing and the recruitment, development, training, and retention of the health workforce in developing countries, especially in least developed countries and small island developing States.
3.c.1 Health worker density and distribution

Country: Global
APN role: All roles
Schober et al 32
3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risk.
3.d.1 International Health Regulations (IHR) capacity and health emergency preparedness

Country: Singapore
APN role: APN
Yi et al 37

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: APN = advanced practice nurses; CNM = certified nurse midwife; CNS = clinical nurse specialist; NP = nurse practitioner.

ce:article-footnote.ce:note-para: In compliance with standard ethical guidelines, the authors report no relationships with business or industry that would pose a conflict of interest.

head.ce:title: United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal 3 Target Indicators: Examples of Advanced Practice Nurses’ Actions

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In 2015, the United Nations created 17 Sustainable Development Goals. Sustainable Development Goal 3, “Good Health and Wellbeing,” includes 13 health target metric goals. This short report describes how advanced practice nurses (APNs) have addressed Goal 3 around the world. Given the variation in the APN roles internationally, it is important to capture common aspects of projects conducted during the first 5 years of this initiative. This report serves as a template for further evaluations of the importance of APNs in supporting global health policies. These findings inform how the workforce can effectively pursue these goals.

ce:section.ce:para: Nurses make up 59% of all health professionals globally and deliver the bulk of the care. 1 Nursing roles have evolved over the past 50 years, and advanced practice nurse (APN) roles have developed to address diverse communities’ health care needs and disparities. Today, more than 70 countries include the APN role in their nursing workforce. 2 The APN scope of practice is considered beyond that of a generalist nurse and includes providing care to a wide range of populations to address various health care priorities. This brief report examines examples of where and how APNs contribute to global healthcare priorities according to the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goal 3 (SDG3) target indicators.

The 17 UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) came into effect in January 2016. 3 These SDGs address the significant problems faced by the global population. The indicators for “Goal 3: Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all ages” aim to address health promotion, increase life expectancy, decrease maternal and child mortality, reduce the spread of infectious diseases, and improve the environment.
4 In 2017, the UN Statistical Commission further refined the indicators for each of the 17 SDGs. SDG3 has 13 targets and indicators. These targets and indicators reflect key global healthcare priorities. The SDG indicators metadata repository is an online resource that provides access to the latest references from the UN and other international organizations for all the SDG indicators. 5 Metadata entries for each UN SDG3 target indicator have references that help identify the importance of each indicator in relation to healthcare and its delivery.

Given the prevalence of APNs internationally and their contribution to healthcare delivery, a literature search was conducted to identify examples of APN initiatives that addressed UN SDG 3 during the first 5 years. Given this report’s aim, to identify examples that demonstrate how APNs have and could contribute to the achievement of the UN SDGs, a systematic literature review was not conducted. Both Medline and CINAHL databases were searched. The search was limited to English publications and the years 2015 through 2020. The keywords were “advanced practice nurse,” “clinical nurse specialist (CNS),” and “nurse practitioner (NP)” in combination with the 13 target indicators (reported in the middle column of the Table ) of the UN’s SDG3. Publications were reviewed by title and abstract to assess their relevance to the 13 target indicators and identify the reported APN role. Examples of nursing role titles that indicated “advanced practice” and addressed keywords within the indicators of interest were selected from a list of eligible models. Not all publications identified by the initial search are used because the aim was not to provide a comprehensive summary of all relevant APN activity. Examples of APN activities supporting SDG3’s target indicators displayed in the Table were chosen based on their relevance to the SDG3 targets and geographic spread. The latter factor was considered to demonstrate the global reach of APNs. Without this approach, this report would be heavily skewed toward examples from North America. However, the review examined articles published in English, which may have resulted in the exclusion of some reports.

From this review, it is inspiring to see the breadth and depth of APN roles globally and how they are meeting and exceeding the challenge put forward by SDG3. Roles found in the Table highlight the value the APN role adds to the health care system. Through the delivery of care and disease prevention, these roles ensure required care is received. APNs working in various contexts use advanced skills to provide care that contributes to meeting the UN SDG 3 targets.

Instances related to APN roles and direct delivery of care included SDG3.1 (reducing maternal mortality), SDG3.2 (ending preventable mortality of newborns and children under age 5 years), SDG3.3 (ending the epidemic of aids, tuberculosis, malaria, neglected tropical diseases, hepatitis, waterborne diseases, and other communicable diseases), SDG3.4 (reducing mortality related to noncommunicable diseases and promote mental health well-being), SDG3.5 (strengthen the prevention and treatment of substance abuse), SDG3.7 (addressing universal access to sexual and reproductive health care), and SDG3.a (strengthening the implementation of tobacco control). Examples reflect a wide range in the delivery of care and regions from which the articles originated. They exemplify advanced nursing roles’ contribution to direct care priorities.

Finding specific examples for the remaining SDG 3 target indicators was a more complex task. Most of the SDG targets do not directly relate to care delivery of nursing or APN practice. These indicators include SDG3.6 (reducing road traffic accidents), SDG3.8 (achieve universal health care coverage), SDG3.9 (reduce ill associated with chemical, air, water, soil pollution, and contamination), SDG3.b (support vaccine and medicines research), SDG3.c (increase health financing, recruitment training, and development of the health care workforce), and SDG3.d (strengthen early warning, risk reduction, and management of national and global health risk). Although direct care examples were found for road traffic accidents, poisoning, and preparedness for global health risks, most of the other examples were recommendations or policy stances rather than direct APN practice examples.

When reviewing the current literature and how these roles can help, it is evident that nursing plays a crucial role. Care delivered by APNs has been shown to improve health outcomes and increase satisfaction among clients and health care colleagues compared with standard care. 6-11 From the examples reviewed, it was also apparent that global APN roles are most relevant to clinical practice rather than the nonclinical components of SDG 3. Within the literature, there is a clear advocation for all levels of nursing to be involved in direct care and aspects such as policy, finance, and research. 12-15 As such, additional work needs to be done in this area. 16-37

Nursing professionals make up the most significant portion of the health care workforce and are responsible for the majority of health care delivered to individuals. APN roles have developed and demonstrated the ability to administer care using “advanced” knowledge and skills. The UN has highlighted inequities in the living conditions of people around the world and has developed the SDGs as “an urgent call for action by all countries.” Supporting the contribution of APNs’ roles to achieving the SDG3 targets is paramount. The examples within this brief report demonstrate the variety of practices that contribute positively to the UN SDG3 target indicators. The examples highlighted demonstrate the different ways in which APNs contribute to the UN’s SDGs.

Furthermore, it establishes that APNs can effectively and efficiently treat and prevent diseases such as those found within the target indicators of SDG 3. This brief report can guide workforce development and individual APN activities to further pursue these goals in various contexts. 16-37

ce:biography.ce:simple-para: Andrew Scanlon, DNP, NP, is a Senior Lecturer, Department of Nursing, University of Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, and can be contacted at andrew.scanlon@unimelb.edu.au.
Maria Murphy, PhD, RN, is a Lecturer, School of Nursing and Midwifery, La Trobe University, Victoria, Australia.
Janice Smolowitz, PhD, ANP, is a Professor and Dean, School of Nursing, Montclair State University, Montclair, NJ.
Virginia Lewis, PhD, is Research Chair in Community Health, La Trobe University, Victoria, Australia.
